meanings.definition: To divide or categorize into two opposing groups or extremes.
meanings.sent1: The teacher bipolarized the students into two teams for the debate.
meanings.sent2: The political debate bipolarized the nation into two distinct groups.
meanings.sent3: The party game bipolarized the guests into two teams for a fun competition.
meanings.sent4: The artist bipolarized the canvas with bold strokes of contrasting colors.
meanings.sent5: The storm bipolarized the sky, with dark clouds on one side and clear blue sky on the other.

meanings.definition: To cause to have two opposite poles or extremes.
meanings.sent1: The magnet bipolarized the metal, attracting it strongly on one end and repelling it on the other.
meanings.sent2: The controversial topic bipolarized the audience, with some strongly agreeing and others strongly disagreeing.
meanings.sent3: The dessert bipolarized the guests, with some loving the sweetness and others finding it too sugary.
meanings.sent4: The charismatic leader bipolarized the crowd, inspiring intense loyalty in some and strong opposition in others.
meanings.sent5: The new policy bipolarized the employees, with some embracing the change and others resisting it fiercely.
